I mean, should we expect at least external marketing campaigns are never going to come back? And in the light of that, how do you feel confident that your longer-term revenue target is still valid? And then secondarily, can you break out the importance of the U.K. and the U.S. factors driving the revenue downgrade? I can see the data that say you're not losing market share in the U.K. Within your original guidance, were you expecting to increase market share in the U.K.? I mean, how should we think about that?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Yes. Thank you for those questions. And it's -- I think the first question that you are asking is a question which we are all having on our minds. What does this DOJ investigation means for our ability to execute our direct-to-consumer strategy in the U.S.? As I said, the Department of Justice have finished their investigations. They have also played back to us what they have found. And it's our expectation that we will be able to fully run our direct-to-consumer strategies as they were planned to be run. That also includes that we will be able to implement the Care, also the next versions of Care exactly as we expected to do. So we feel that we are in a very comfortable situation in regards to our long-term strategy on a direct-to-consumer in the U.S. In the U.K. and our ability to run the business there, precisely what is it that you're looking for, Ian?

---

【質問: Ian Douglas-Pennant (Analysts)】
Sorry, in terms of the guidance downgrade for the year, you helped us think about the -- where the EBIT downgrade is coming or the EBIT margin guidance downgrade for the revenue margin downgrade. I mean, is the U.K. just as important as the U.S. in terms of where your disappointment has come from? Or is one more important than the other?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
That's a very good question. It's -- I don't know if we are able to, at this point in time, split out exactly how that is. We have half of the downgrade on the EBIT comes from the revenue loss, so to say, or the missing revenue and the other half comes from the -- and that is from U.S. and U.K. And the other half comes from the 3 things that I mentioned: on Department of Justice, on Southern Europe and so on. So the half that comes from U.S. and U.K., that's the one that you like to have split out further. But I haven't prepared for that. But I would say that U.K. is, of course, important to us. And that's probably a bit more than half. But that's just back of the envelope.

---

【質問: Alexander Kleban (Analysts)】
I had 2. So first one, and I ask that you can give us as much detail as you can, but how closely aligned do you think the provision you're taking on DOJ will be with the ultimate settlement or release with the kind of conversations you're having now with the DOJ? And then I'll ask a second one as a follow-up.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
I'm not sure I follow your question. Could you elaborate just a little bit?

---

【質問: Alexander Kleban (Analysts)】
Well, in other words -- yes, so you're taking a provision here and you're in discussions with DOJ. You've received what sounds like a final kind of ruling from them or at least final opinion from them. To what extent is that provision you're taking -- and you mentioned a settlement. Is that going to be close to what we would need to think about for the settlement you could potentially make? Or is it too early to say?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Since we haven't finished all of our negotiations, so to speak, it's -- I can't be final. This is our estimate. But it's an estimate based on what we know, and we know quite a bit at this point in time.

---

【質問: Alexander Kleban (Analysts)】
And is that driven by in terms of, a, amount of sales that you've had in the U.S., amount of profitability you've had in the U.S.? Can you give us some color on what factors are going into that provision?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
No. Since we have not finished that, we cannot give you more flavor on it. But if we didn't feel that we were within a range which we feel is certain, then we would not talk about it.

---

【質問: Alexander Kleban (Analysts)】
Okay, fair enough. And then the second question was just on Surgical Urology in the U.S. So that was weak last quarter. Is anything in the guidance downgrade related to Surgical Urology? And how has that looked in the U.S. in the quarter?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Well, I can't update you on the current quarter, apart from what we say on the U.S. and the U.K. So we'll come back to that when we finish the quarter. But everything that we learned, maybe I should just give you a few more insights on this, the reason why we are at this point in time coming with a change to guidance, every month, we have a monthly performance review, where we go through the performance of the different units and also their take on the future. And we had such a meeting yesterday. And it's basically based on the 2 things that I talked about here that we have changed our guidance. So it's -- those are the explanations.

---

【質問: Alexander Kleban (Analysts)】
Okay. So I guess, it's fair to say then that at this stage, what you know of Surgical Urology this far is actually already factored into what you're doing today. Okay, that's all for me.

---

【質問: Martin Brunninger (Analysts)】
I have just one question actually, please. You said you have not lost market share despite the factors that you mentioned in the U.K -- yes, I know. Have you won market share in a declining market, you think? Or do you think that -- and can you catch up with that trend? Maybe you can elaborate on that a little bit because it seems like you've mentioned it on the last call as well as it seems like it could become a chronic problem.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Yes, that what could become a chronic problem?

---

【質問: Martin Brunninger (Analysts)】
The situation in the U.K. with the homecare business, the one you...

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Well, okay. Thank you very much. That's -- I think you are touching on a very important topic. That's -- what does this mean for the future of the U.K. Charter business? I think that we come out -- we will come out very strongly off this. But of course, we have lost customers in the homecare business, there's no doubt about that. We have probably primarily lost customers that are not using Coloplast products because we are serving everybody who's in the market, and we are having all competitors' products at the shelf also. But do I expect that we will start to grow from the new level that we have when we are fully through this? Of course, I do. But do I see that we are -- that things are progressing extremely well in the U.K. when it comes to Ostomy and the launch of new Mio? Yes, definitely. And we're also now launching a SpeediCath Compact Eve in the U.K. So I actually expect us to be very strong again in the U.K. when we are on the other side of this. The fact that we -- even though that we have so big problems as we have right now in the U.K., the fact that we are not losing market share in this situation just speaks to the strength of the business that we have and the strength of the product portfolio. So I take this as a low point from where we are actually progressing quite well.

---

【質問: Martin Brunninger (Analysts)】
And you don't think there will be pricing pressures following that trend? I mean, I'm just thinking of the homecare business. On the service side, Healthcare at Home, they have been quite successful and the NHS has put so much pressure, and then the EBIT margin has gone really down significantly. Is there a risk from the product side as well? From what you're doing is slightly different, I appreciate that. But still remains a trend that the NHS is putting quite a lot of pressure on prices at the moment.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
I think that the pricing pressure that we see is not bigger at this point in time than at any other point in time over the last few years, where we also had the financial crisis. I can't see why this change or our current problems, which basically are unfortunately Coloplast problems, why they would trigger any further price pressure than what we see now. We'll live with the price pressure. We have done that for many years and they are here to stay, we know that. But I don't see that accelerating in the U.K.

---

【質問: Edward Ridley-Day (Analysts)】
Firstly, just on guidance. Lars, if I could follow up on the guidance. You're obviously maintaining your longer-term EBIT margin development guidance. Is that sort of 50 to 100 basis points a year from the -- as it where underlying margin guidance that you're giving full year '15 of what is roughly 33% or from the reported margin? That will be my first question.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Yes, that's a very good question. And we will come back to that when we are guiding for the new year. It's not a question that we have been preparing for, for today.

---

【質問: Edward Ridley-Day (Analysts)】
Okay, fair enough. And just to follow up on Devon Medical, I don't know if you want to take the opportunity to talk about that just in terms of the -- what has been going on there and should we say, the Devon Medical response, which is in the market.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
But there's -- are you talking about the legal case or what...

---

【質問: Edward Ridley-Day (Analysts)】
Yes, exactly. If you could just...

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
But it's an ongoing case. It's important -- or it's impossible for me really to comment on it. We -- it's actually -- we're just in a situation here where we say, "Let's take out of the books what we have because this is a legal situation." So that's why we do it. But I can't comment on the -- on the ongoing case. It's hardly started. It's very new actually.

---

【質問: Veronika Dubajova (Analysts)】
I just have a couple of question follow-ups on the DOJ investigation. And I think the first one is why do you think the scrutiny or the level of marketing activities has decelerated so significantly in the last quarter or so? And then as a follow-up to that, appreciate that you feel that your activities won't be impacted, but have you had the same conversations with your dealers and distributors? And do you sense that once the -- do you sense actually from them that once the investigation disappears, they are happy to resume the activities as they used to with you?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
It's a little bit of a rippling effect because it started with Coloplast, and then you have seen that over time, it's been spreading to the distributors. So therefore, we are much further progressed in this matter than the other parties involved at this point in time. So therefore, we know about the business practices that we have had in the past. And of course, I can only vouch for what I know about Coloplast and the business practices that we have been conducting. And we see no reason why we should not be able to run direct campaigns going forward. But of course, we need to see that the dealers will go through with the same processes as we have been through.

---

【質問: Veronika Dubajova (Analysts)】
Okay. And do you, Lars, have any views on when that process might conclude for them?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
No.

---

【質問: Veronika Dubajova (Analysts)】
Okay. And then if I were to look at your medium-term guidance of 7% to 10% top line growth and assume that you're unable to do any marketing activities via dealers and distributors and instead any activities that you undertake have to be direct on your behalf, do you venture a guess for what that guidance range would look like under that scenario?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
No. But that's a very good question. I think I'll park that for next time that we're giving guidance because that's probably relevant to speak about.

---

【質問: Martin Parkhoi (Analysts)】
Yes, 2 questions, again back to the U.S. market. I just want to dig a little bit a little bit more into it because as you say, you see some lost sales from lack of campaign activity. Do you know if this has actually hurt market growth for the products where you're affected? Or is it isolated, U.S. been hurt because, I guess, there's at least another of your competitors, which also is included in the...

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
No, that's -- maybe if I take that first because that's a good question. What we said in the first quarter was that we could see that our assessment was impacted on -- we have a lot of assessment sales last year due to our direct campaign activities and it's been much harder for us to lift this year because we have not had the same kind of pressure on the markets. So I would actually expect that in the U.S. that we have -- we are probably impacting the growth of the assessment market. But I'm guessing, I don't have facts to underline this. But I'm just saying that we have significantly lower sales on assessments this year and we see significantly lower price in the market.

---

【質問: Martin Parkhoi (Analysts)】
And then second question, just to be 100% sure. Does this have any kind of impact on your investments on the additional sales initiatives both for this year and for the coming years?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
As we said at the Capital Markets Day not long ago, then we have decided to keep the pressure on the investments because we fully acknowledge that top line growth is extremely important and we think that the long-term guidance we have is the right one. We think that is still valid. And therefore, we keep investing to deliver in that specific range that we have laid out, which is 7% to 10% top line growth and 50 to 100 basis point expansion on the bottom line every year.

---

【質問: Martin Parkhoi (Analysts)】
But the expansion that you had expected for U.K., I guess, that is not -- which I guess you had in some steps, I guess that is not folding out as you initially had expected?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
For this year?

---

【質問: Martin Parkhoi (Analysts)】
Yes.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
I have to say that, well, this year is -- in that sense, this year is extremely difficult because when we did the guidance for this year, we had absolutely no idea about the issues that we -- that have unfolded in the U.K. So I consider that to be a one-off. And I think that we have dealt and are dealing with it in the most strongest way that we're able to do. And that's certainly not something that I expect to see every year. Mind you that this year, well, we're going to deliver 7% growth in a year where we see -- where we don't see at all the impact growth-wise that we would expect to see from both U.S. and U.K. They are our #1 and 2 biggest markets at all, and they're not performing like they should. So that talks a little bit to what the rest of the business is really doing.

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Okay. I have, I think, 3 questions. The first question is relating to the external campaigns that you're able to run. When do you think you could initiate that for yourself? And to what extent do you actually require the collaboration of your distributors for that to have a meaningful impact on your business? And then the second question is on Greece. I think you've had -- you've been in this sort of situation before at the height of the financial crisis. But can you give us some color on how big of a, I suppose, challenge that your distributor is facing this time around relative to last time? And how much of a provision you actually had to use last time? And then the third question is on the, I suppose, the relative sizes -- or the NPWT writeoff, that seems to be -- you're in a pilot launch. So I was kind of surprised that you actually mentioned that as a factor, given that it should be quite immaterial as a factor.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Yes, Anders will talk to Greece and the Negative Pressure Wound Therapy. So he will start out with that.

---

【回答: Anders Lonning-Skovgaard (Executives)】
So in terms of Greece, yes, in 2008, 2009, there was also some financial challenges in Greece. But we managed also in that period to handle our Greece business without any bad debt. This time, we also see some challenges due to the economic situation in Greece and we have decided to make a provision for bad debt in Greece. I'm not going to disclose any numbers. In relation to the second question around NPWT, can you just repeat that?

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Yes. So the -- I think part of the, I suppose, nonrevenue-driven downgrade to your margin you mentioned is due to writing down the NPWT inventory. My understanding is that you're in a pilot launch. And so I wasn't expecting there to be much inventory at all, so somewhat surprised that you actually mentioned it. Perhaps that is bigger than what I thought it would be. Could you comment on that?

---

【回答: Anders Lonning-Skovgaard (Executives)】
So the NPWT, as you might recall, we had a pilot in Brazil, in Switzerland and also in Greece. And then we, over the autumn and the winter, started to plan for a global launch. And that's why we have had a stock related to that. But due to the safety situation of the product, we decided to stop the cooperation with Devon.

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Okay. So maybe it would be helpful to just comment, I suppose, prioritize the size of the 3 nonrevenue-related downgrades to your margin, which is the biggest and which is the smallest, will be helpful...

---

【回答: Anders Lonning-Skovgaard (Executives)】
We are not going to disclose any further on that at this point in time.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
When it comes to the external campaigns or the campaigns that we're doing in the U.S., as it's quite clear right now, we are very limited in our abilities to do external campaigns. Actually, they have come to a complete full stop, which means that we are running internal campaigns, which we can do, of course. But it is with the way that we are running our business in the U.S. right now, it's more -- it has more traction when we do it in a collaboration with external partners. But of course, this means that we will have to look at how can we step up our abilities to do internal campaigns and to run more growth that way around. And that's just how it is. I can't give you a time frame on when the Department of Justice is fully done. And therefore, it's hard for me to comment on the timing of this.

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Okay. So you won't be able to start any internal -- when you say internal, you mean just Coloplast-only campaigns?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
That is actually -- those are running as we speak.

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Okay. So then it's only the external ones that the Department of Justice is limiting you on at this stage.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
No, they are not limiting us. What we are saying here is that because we -- I think that we have all been in doubt what is it that the Department of Justice is really looking for. Now we are -- we know what is the outcome for Coloplast because that is where we at this point in time. And we feel that we are ready now to go to do also external campaigns. But you need an external partner in order to do that. And the external partners are still under investigation. So they do not have the same clarity on the business practices as we have. And therefore, we don't do any external campaigns right now because the dealers, they have the same doubts as we had. So what is this really about?

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Okay. And do you have any sense of how soon after the DOJ started speaking to you that they started to speak to the dealers, like how much of a lag that there has been?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Well, I can't guide you on that and I don't even know if -- because they have completely different scale of business than what we have many of them, so I wouldn't know what's the process and so on. So yes.

---

【質問: Yi-Dan Wang (Analysts)】
Okay. But the bottom line is you don't need to change much of what you've been planning.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
No.

---

【質問: Soren Hansen (Analysts)】
So just a timing thing that we could start to see these activities resume again.

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
Yes.

---

【質問: Oliver Metzger (Analysts)】
There's only one question left. Do you think that beneath the lower marketing activities in the U.S. were also a factor of more aggressive pricing of a competitor in [indiscernible], which had potentially a negative impact on guidance on U.S. market?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
What? I don't think so. We also have Mio in the U.S. market now and we see -- we actually see that the interest is very high. We are winning several hospitals with this new assortment. So I don't see that. And yes. So no, I have to say no to that.

---

【質問: Scott Bardo (Analysts)】
I'm quite encouraged to hear that you feel that you can continue with your direct-to-consumer initiatives in the North American market, obviously contingent on the master dealers also sort of concurring with your vision. What I'm interested to understand is do you see heightened compliance costs or an increased level of regulation? Can you discount the fact that you're entering into some Deferred Prosecution Agreement or some sort of Corporate Integrity Agreement of which might, if you like, limit or regulate some of the activities in North America? So that would be one question, please. And just a follow-up, do you think any of this activity limits the company's ability to secure GPO contracts in Ostomy or thence the strategy of value upgrading SpeediCath into the U.S. at the time of sort of patent expiry 2017?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
I don't think that -- and I have to say that we are quite advanced in these negotiations. I don't see that we will have any extra burden of either cost or processes in order to conduct our business in the U.S. I think we fully understand where we are, and so over and -- I don't think that has anything over and above the constant pressure, which you always have on a business to make sure that when you run a global business that you are compliant with both local regulation and your own code of conduct. And that is issues that we are always working on to make sure that we are compliant. But apart from that, no, I don't think that this is going to have any impact.

---

【質問: Scott Bardo (Analysts)】
And also you'd extend those comments through your potential to get on GPO contracts and your sort of value upgrade strategies of SpeediCath, you don't think that these things are connected at all or shouldn't be impacted by these developments?

---

【回答: Lars Rasmussen (Executives)】
I think it's a very good question. It's hard for me to say yes or no to this because I wouldn't expect it to. But it's not, of course, an area where I have a complete insight. But yes, I don't expect that, Scott. Okay, thank you very much for the interest. And this is the conclusion of the meeting.

BP9DL90.eventHeadline: Industria de Diseno Textil SA, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 10, 2015
BP9DL90.transcript_text1:
Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex results for the interim 3 months 2015. I am Pablo Isla. Here with me today are Ignacio Fernández, our CFO; and Marcos López, Capital Markets Director. 
The results for the interim 3 months 2015 show that Inditex continues its global multi-concept, multi-channel growth. We enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates the stores and online and offers huge growth opportunities. 
Inditex operating performance in the period has been strong. Sales have increased 17%. Our operations have also shown high efficiency and tight operating control over the period. As a result, EBIT has grown 25%. 
Let me also tell you that in terms of expansion, space growth and online launches for the year are on track. In terms of growth, we have maintained the strong pace of expansion. We have opened stores in 27 different markets over the period, demonstrating the global reach of Inditex business model. We have continued our global online rollout. We have a global presence and have further diversified our operations over the period. We continue to see significant growth opportunities for Inditex globally. 
The year so far has been marked by very strong activity on many fronts. I would like to cover a number of recent initiatives carried out by Inditex. We have reinforced significantly the differentiation of our key global flagships with very visible openings. 
Starting with Zara, I would like to highlight those stores opened recently: first, this remarkable store at 61 Oxford Street in London; second, the enlargement of the store at Xidan Joy City in Beijing, a unique location and one of our most emblematic stores worldwide. Bershka is rolling out its new image. This is reflected in its flagship store in Torino. Massimo Dutti is offering a personal tailoring service at its recently refurbished global flagship at la Madeleine, Paris, that reopened at the end of May. Pull&Bear has recently launched a global flagship store in Shanghai's East Nanjing Road. Stradivarius has opened a flagship store of 1,200 square meters at Madero in Mexico. Oysho has moved to a new headquarters and distribution center in Tordera. The new building comprises 50,000 square meters. Oysho has also launched a new store image. This is reflected in its flagship in Paseo de Gracia at Barcelona. Zara Home has recently enlarged its global flagship store in Milan's Piazza San Babila to 2,700 square meters, making it the largest Zara Home store worldwide. Zara Home also continues its global online rollout with its recent launch in Japan. And Uterqüe has opened a store with its new image in Madrid Airport. 
Inditex is in a unique situation as we enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates stores and online as the best way to respond to the demands of our customers. This is a result of our highly differentiated business model, with a central inventory position, distribution to all our stores globally at least twice a week and orders received by our customers between 2 and 48 hours. This factor works perfectly in conjunction with our global online sales presence. We believe that Inditex is in an excellent position to take advantage of global growth opportunities. We have a strong potential to continue expanding profitably in the coming years. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio, who will present some of the key aspects of our financial performance, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

Thank you. In the first quarter of 2015, Inditex has had a strong operating performance. All the key lines of the profit and loss account show significant growth. Net sales reached EUR 4.4 billion; EBITDA, EUR 895 million; and net income, EUR 521 million. 
In the first quarter 2015, sales have grown 17%. Like-for-like sales growth has been strong, and store and online launches for the year are on track. Sales growth in local currencies was 13%. Set currencies remain at current levels. We estimate 2% at least on sales for fiscal year 2015.
Gross profit has increased 18% to EUR 2.6 billion, resulting a 59.4% gross margin on sales. We have sustained our commercial policies over the period. 
Operating expenses are tightly under control. They have grown 15%, reflecting mainly the growth in space and sales. They include all the startup costs for new openings. 
Operating working capital remains negative as a result of the business model. The working capital evolution is in line with the performance of the business. 
I will now hand over to Marcos, who'll elaborate on the performance of the Inditex concepts.

---

In terms of space addition and online launches, we are on track. Continuing with our global expansion, we have opened stores in 27 markets in the first quarter of the year. Global online launches continue at a very rapid pace. 
Regarding the performance by concept in the interim 3 months 2015, Zara continues to represent approximately 2/3 of group sales; the younger concepts, around 1/3. The younger concepts, grouped together, have performed satisfactorily. I would like to highlight that Stradivarius, Zara Home and Uterqüe have performed very strongly. 
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

Thank you, Marcos. With respect to expansion in 2015, let me highlight that space growth and online launches are on track. Ordinary capital expenditure for 2015 will be around EUR 1.35 billion. For the coming years, we'll continue to see strong growth opportunities, with capital expenditure growing below space growth. 
Regarding the outlook for the first half of 2015, I would like to add that store and online sales in local currencies from the 1st of February to the 7th of June have grown by 13.5%. 
Just as a reminder, we made our initial 2014 dividend payment of EUR 809 million on the 4th of May. We will continue to invest in the expansion of our business across a number of markets, all of which offer attractive long-term returns through our sales platform that fully integrates stores and online. 
Inditex is present on 5 continents and in all the key markets, demonstrating the group's global reach. We manage a diversified sales platform in 88 markets, and the current base offers huge growth potential for the coming years.
Inditex online operations have seen a very rapid growth in recent years. Our business model allows a swift expansion of our online sales globally. Zara has built an online sales presence in 21 European markets, the United States, China, the Russian Federation, Japan, South Korea, Mexico and Canada, the world's main economies. The concepts also have an established online sales presence in Europe. Additionally, some of the concepts are present in the United States. We will continue to roll out online sales progressively in all the markets in which we are present with the stores. A step in this direction will be the launch of Zara online sales in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in the autumn/winter season. 
Before closing, I would like to highlight some selected Zara store openings from recent months. I would like to begin with the flagship store that Zara has opened recently in Amsterdam. The new Zara flagship at Toison d’Or in Brussels has very strong architectural features. Zara has recently enlarged its Hamburg flagship store to 4,000 square meters. The store at Copenhagen has also been enlarged to 4,000 square meters. The Zara store in Vladivostock is housed in the GUM historical building. We have enlarged and introduced the new image at our store in Tokyo's iconic Ikebukuro district. We have opened a flagship store in Em Quartier in Bangkok. Finally, our newest store in Urumqui has been extremely well received. This is store #510 in China.  
And this is all from us. We will be pleased to answer any question you may have.
BP9DL90.transcript_text2:
【プレゼン: Pablo De Tejera (Executives)】
Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex results for the interim 3 months 2015. I am Pablo Isla. Here with me today are Ignacio Fernández, our CFO; and Marcos López, Capital Markets Director. 
The results for the interim 3 months 2015 show that Inditex continues its global multi-concept, multi-channel growth. We enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates the stores and online and offers huge growth opportunities. 
Inditex operating performance in the period has been strong. Sales have increased 17%. Our operations have also shown high efficiency and tight operating control over the period. As a result, EBIT has grown 25%. 
Let me also tell you that in terms of expansion, space growth and online launches for the year are on track. In terms of growth, we have maintained the strong pace of expansion. We have opened stores in 27 different markets over the period, demonstrating the global reach of Inditex business model. We have continued our global online rollout. We have a global presence and have further diversified our operations over the period. We continue to see significant growth opportunities for Inditex globally. 
The year so far has been marked by very strong activity on many fronts. I would like to cover a number of recent initiatives carried out by Inditex. We have reinforced significantly the differentiation of our key global flagships with very visible openings. 
Starting with Zara, I would like to highlight those stores opened recently: first, this remarkable store at 61 Oxford Street in London; second, the enlargement of the store at Xidan Joy City in Beijing, a unique location and one of our most emblematic stores worldwide. Bershka is rolling out its new image. This is reflected in its flagship store in Torino. Massimo Dutti is offering a personal tailoring service at its recently refurbished global flagship at la Madeleine, Paris, that reopened at the end of May. Pull&Bear has recently launched a global flagship store in Shanghai's East Nanjing Road. Stradivarius has opened a flagship store of 1,200 square meters at Madero in Mexico. Oysho has moved to a new headquarters and distribution center in Tordera. The new building comprises 50,000 square meters. Oysho has also launched a new store image. This is reflected in its flagship in Paseo de Gracia at Barcelona. Zara Home has recently enlarged its global flagship store in Milan's Piazza San Babila to 2,700 square meters, making it the largest Zara Home store worldwide. Zara Home also continues its global online rollout with its recent launch in Japan. And Uterqüe has opened a store with its new image in Madrid Airport. 
Inditex is in a unique situation as we enjoy a global sales platform that fully integrates stores and online as the best way to respond to the demands of our customers. This is a result of our highly differentiated business model, with a central inventory position, distribution to all our stores globally at least twice a week and orders received by our customers between 2 and 48 hours. This factor works perfectly in conjunction with our global online sales presence. We believe that Inditex is in an excellent position to take advantage of global growth opportunities. We have a strong potential to continue expanding profitably in the coming years. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio, who will present some of the key aspects of our financial performance, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

【プレゼン: Ignacio Izuzquiza Fernández (Executives)】
Thank you. In the first quarter of 2015, Inditex has had a strong operating performance. All the key lines of the profit and loss account show significant growth. Net sales reached EUR 4.4 billion; EBITDA, EUR 895 million; and net income, EUR 521 million. 
In the first quarter 2015, sales have grown 17%. Like-for-like sales growth has been strong, and store and online launches for the year are on track. Sales growth in local currencies was 13%. Set currencies remain at current levels. We estimate 2% at least on sales for fiscal year 2015.
Gross profit has increased 18% to EUR 2.6 billion, resulting a 59.4% gross margin on sales. We have sustained our commercial policies over the period. 
Operating expenses are tightly under control. They have grown 15%, reflecting mainly the growth in space and sales. They include all the startup costs for new openings. 
Operating working capital remains negative as a result of the business model. The working capital evolution is in line with the performance of the business. 
I will now hand over to Marcos, who'll elaborate on the performance of the Inditex concepts.

---

【プレゼン: Marcos García (Executives)】
In terms of space addition and online launches, we are on track. Continuing with our global expansion, we have opened stores in 27 markets in the first quarter of the year. Global online launches continue at a very rapid pace. 
Regarding the performance by concept in the interim 3 months 2015, Zara continues to represent approximately 2/3 of group sales; the younger concepts, around 1/3. The younger concepts, grouped together, have performed satisfactorily. I would like to highlight that Stradivarius, Zara Home and Uterqüe have performed very strongly. 
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

【プレゼン: Pablo De Tejera (Executives)】
Thank you, Marcos. With respect to expansion in 2015, let me highlight that space growth and online launches are on track. Ordinary capital expenditure for 2015 will be around EUR 1.35 billion. For the coming years, we'll continue to see strong growth opportunities, with capital expenditure growing below space growth. 
Regarding the outlook for the first half of 2015, I would like to add that store and online sales in local currencies from the 1st of February to the 7th of June have grown by 13.5%. 
Just as a reminder, we made our initial 2014 dividend payment of EUR 809 million on the 4th of May. We will continue to invest in the expansion of our business across a number of markets, all of which offer attractive long-term returns through our sales platform that fully integrates stores and online. 
Inditex is present on 5 continents and in all the key markets, demonstrating the group's global reach. We manage a diversified sales platform in 88 markets, and the current base offers huge growth potential for the coming years.
Inditex online operations have seen a very rapid growth in recent years. Our business model allows a swift expansion of our online sales globally. Zara has built an online sales presence in 21 European markets, the United States, China, the Russian Federation, Japan, South Korea, Mexico and Canada, the world's main economies. The concepts also have an established online sales presence in Europe. Additionally, some of the concepts are present in the United States. We will continue to roll out online sales progressively in all the markets in which we are present with the stores. A step in this direction will be the launch of Zara online sales in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in the autumn/winter season. 
Before closing, I would like to highlight some selected Zara store openings from recent months. I would like to begin with the flagship store that Zara has opened recently in Amsterdam. The new Zara flagship at Toison d’Or in Brussels has very strong architectural features. Zara has recently enlarged its Hamburg flagship store to 4,000 square meters. The store at Copenhagen has also been enlarged to 4,000 square meters. The Zara store in Vladivostock is housed in the GUM historical building. We have enlarged and introduced the new image at our store in Tokyo's iconic Ikebukuro district. We have opened a flagship store in Em Quartier in Bangkok. Finally, our newest store in Urumqui has been extremely well received. This is store #510 in China.  
And this is all from us. We will be pleased to answer any question you may have.
BP9DL90.transcript_text3:
My question is about Zara Home, and I'm wondering if you can explain why it continues to outperform. I know it had 2 very strong years already, and it looks like it's outperforming in Q1 as well. And then talk about where you're rolling that out because you mentioned the global rollout. So are you focusing on any particular countries there?

---

Well, thank you. What we can tell you is that we are very pleased with the performance of Zara Home. And we are doing 2 different things. In one hand, we are enlarging the existing stores. We have mentioned during the presentation the example of Piazza San Babila, which is the, I would say, the most relevant global flagship of Zara Home. And at the same time, we are opening stores in very relevant locations, such as Aoyama in Tokyo or Bourke Street in Melbourne. Well, we also are developing or rolling out the online presence of Zara Home in key markets globally. We also have mentioned that we have recently launched the online sales in Japan. What we can say is that Zara Home is a very good brand, which is being very well accepted and received in all the different markets. And what we are thinking to do is to continue developing the brand.

---

Okay. So any particular markets where you've been expanding faster with Zara Home?

---

No, I would say we are opening our stores globally. We are building a strong presence in Europe, we are opening in the relevant Asian markets, and we have also presence in the Americas, so we'll continue with the -- I would say -- I wouldn't mention any specific geography. We think it's a brand with very strong potential. As I was saying to you, it's very well received in all the different markets.

---

Could you just talk a little bit more about the LFL performance in the quarter in terms of which markets were stronger or less strong and also where you put prices up and how relevant that price increases were to the LFL performance in the quarter?

---

Thank you. What we can say is that like-for-like sales growth, we have had very strong operating performance and with positive like-for-like sales growth in all the different geographies. You know that we don't like to elaborate very much on this or that country at -- particularly in a quarter because we prefer always to wait until the full year or at least until the end of the season. But what we can say is that we have had a strong like-for-like performance in the different markets in this first quarter. And this like-for-like sales growth is volume driven, so our pricing policy globally has been to maintain stable prices in the different markets. That is the global pricing policy. There could be one exception here or there in one sense or the other, but globally, as we always say, our prices have remained stable in the different markets. If -- in fact, if you analyze our average selling price over the years, you see that it is very, very stable. Particularly if you think about the last year, the year 2014, it was around EUR 17.5, our average selling price, and it has been the same in the last 10 or 15 years, so a stable pricing policy in the different markets.

---

But presumably, in markets where FX has been particularly weak, like Russia or Japan, you have had to adjust for that, have you?

---

But you must have in mind that we operate a global business. We are present in 88 different markets. We have lots of markets, so I think it's not particularly relevant to mention this or that specific country. What I can tell you is a stable pricing policy as the global policy of the company.

---

I've got a couple of questions for you, please. Firstly, do you think that you're seeing a benefit of the weaker euro, such as translating through improved tourism into Euroland revenues? And secondly, can you talk about Spain and your views ahead of the sort of second half on the general elections?

---

Well, what I would say is that, well, you know that we always prefer not to enter into macroeconomic questions or this type of things. What we can say is that we are happy with the evolution of our business in the different European markets. What we can say about the external environment is that we could say that it's a reasonable environment for us to continue developing our business and to continue growing in the different markets. In particular, about the Spanish market, you were mentioning, well, we said in the full year results presentation that in the year 2014, we achieved 5% sales growth in Spain, which was a very, I would say, well, strong or consistent sales growth. And what we can tell you is that in this year, we continue with this positive evolution in the Spanish market.

---

Okay. And then just in terms of your full year tax charge, please, do you have any guidance given? I think it was 23.7% in the first quarter.

---

Yes. You know that our tax -- quarterly tax charge is always the best estimate for the year, so this is the guidance we can provide.

---

Just a quick one on your space rollout. Obviously, if you look at your number of stores, they grew by about 5.5% year-on-year; and Zara, about 5%. You've talked on the call about enlarging a number of stores, but I just wanted to be clear. Your longer-term store rollout -- space rollouts or store rollouts targets, the 8% to 10%, you still feel that, that's certainly achievable for, say, the medium term? And would that be more going into new countries? Or do you think it's more about deepening the stores across the concepts in existing geographies? And which ones would those be?

---

Yes. Well, first of all, what I would say is that, as you were mentioning, for us, what is relevant is space growth much more than the number of openings because space growth is a combination between opening new stores; as you know, we are also absorbing small stores; and then also enlarging existing stores. So in terms of our space growth, as we said in the full year result presentation in March, we'll continue seeing this 8% to 10% space growth. We operate in 88 different markets with 8 different brands, so this means that we are finding very good space growth opportunities. And the second part of your question, it's always a combination of both between the possibility of new countries and then deepening our presence in the markets in which we are already present. You must have in mind that in most of the markets in which we are already present, our market share is below 1%, so this is going to be the main engine of future space growth. Of course, there could also always be new markets, but we have -- as we were saying during the presentation, we continue seeing a strong growth opportunities in the different markets. In any particular year, we are opening stores. Last year, I think it was in 54 different countries; in this first quarter, in 27 different countries. So this year, you could expect us opening stores in 50 or in 60 different markets over the year. So that is why we continue seeing this space growth rate. It has a lot to do with this global presence.

---

Okay, that's helpful. Just a quick -- just last one, on the dividend, obviously, your cash balances remain robust. When you look forward, even though you've got the negative working capital, any comments sort of over the next 12 to 24 months on the dividend policy, either in terms of the payout ratio or potential for other returns of cash to shareholders?

---

Yes, what -- you know that we like to -- we always update about the dividend policy in the full year results presentation, and of course, we are generating significant cash flows. Our first priority is always to invest in the long-term profitable growth of the company, but because of this strong cash flow generation, we are able to combine this with what we consider an attractive and predictable shareholders remuneration policy. We have this stated policy of 50% payout and then the possibility of extraordinary dividends. And regarding 2014 results, what the Board of Directors decided was to propose to the shareholders' meeting a 7% increase in the dividend. This was, if I am right, 63% payout ratio. Well, what we can say is that we have more than doubled the dividend in the last 5 years, and our idea is to continue with this same policy, with this type of approach. But in any case, the moment in which we like always to talk about the dividend is the full year results presentation.

---

I just wanted to ask a question on the gross margin. It was obviously up 50 basis points year-over-year in the first quarter. Sales momentum clearly seems like it's been strong going into Q2, which I guess would suggest that you should continue to do well on markdown. But on the other hand, clearly, FX is essentially [ph] negative if you can't offset with pricing and other initiatives. Do you maintain the view that stability is the best expectation for -- or the central expectation for the year?

---

Yes. As you know, and as we always say, the gross margin is a combination of many different things: fashion trends, say, product mix, like for likes, markups, markdowns, currencies, the comparable, so -- and at the same time, you know that our business model is very flexible, and then it provides stability to the gross margins. This is why in the full year results presentation, we were talking about a stable gross margin for the year. We always say that stable for us means plus/minus 50 basis points. What we can say is that at current exchange rates, our best estimate is for a broadly stable gross margin for 2015. It is true that this year, probably a bit higher in the first half and a bit lower in the second half given the evolution of the U.S. dollar-euro exchange rate. But globally, a stable gross margin for the year.

---

And also, in light of the guidance around CapEx growing slower than space growth in the years ahead, just wondered if you could give a bit more color to understand how much slower it would grow, whether you actually can -- would expect it to grow in absolute terms, and whether we're talking about a couple of percent variance or quite substantial leverage of that investment you put into prior years.

---

Yes. It's difficult to be very specific about any particular figure of difference between space growth and CapEx growth. What we would -- what we can tell you is what you already know, that after this period in which we have invested strongly in logistics, in IT, with some extraordinary CapEx from that point of view, what we see this year and the coming years is CapEx growth to be below space growth. Then in [ph] any particular year, that would always be 1 point, 2 points, so it's very difficult to be more precise, but you should expect, in any case, CapEx growth below space growth in the coming years.

---

Would you be prepared to say how much of your CapEx bill every year is on square meter expansion?

---

It would -- 80%, 85%. Well, expansion and refurbishments, I would say, around 85% of the CapEx in a normal year. And then there are some years, as it has been in the past few years, in which logistics represent a more relevant part of that CapEx.

---

I got a question on import tariffs. It seems quite significant changes recently I noticed, particularly in China over the last 10 days or so. Could you say what your position is there? Will you see a benefit in terms of your gross margin in China and -- or whether you will pass that benefit through in the form of lower retail prices?

---

Yes. Thank you, Andy. Regarding what you comment, the change in tariffs regards very specific product categories, so the impact in our gross margin is very, very small. And to give you some color, I think the only category in which there is some kind of impact is [indiscernible] in the categories in which we operate, it doesn't affect us.

---

Okay. Are there any other changes in any other markets in terms of import tariffs that we should be aware of?

---

Not significant.

---

Just one question from me, please, on productivity initiatives. I wondered if you could just give an update, in particular, on the radio frequency technology in stores. It sounds like that's giving some productivity benefits for Zara. And so I wonder if you can say how much of that technology now are being rolled out across the Zara estate and also for the other formats, please.

---

Well, what we can tell you is that RFID is helping a lot in the way we operate the stores. It has to do with everything related with the store operations. Of course, the main target for us implementing RFID has to do with customer service. But then it's helping a lot in terms of the way we receive the product in the store, the way we replenish from the stockroom to the floor, the inventories, so it is helping a lot from every point of view. I think it's a very positive change in terms of the way we operate and we manage the stores. We continue with the rollout in Zara. At the end of this year, we will be present in around 1,500 Zara stores in the world, and then we will begin the rollout in the -- with the other brands. It's something which is -- we think it's a very positive change in the way we operate the stores from every point of view. I don't know, but probably you have had the opportunity to see how it works in Guangzhou, in one particular store, and it has really changed completely the way we control the stock. But mainly, the main target behind RFID is customer service. So now we can offer our customers a much better service from the point of view of the service we offer them; also, from the point of view that we can check immediately if it's available or not, then we offer them the possibility to order online from the stores if this is the case. So RFID combined with online, this full integration between stores and online, is something which is, we think, a big and positive change in the way we manage our stores.

---

Okay. So it sounds like there is some -- the Zara estate, it will be mostly rolled out by the end of this year, and then there will be a little bit more to do next year. Is that right for Zara?

---

Yes. Yes, yes, that's right.

---

And then the net -- the other formats will be rolled out next year mainly?

---

Yes.

---

Good morning. So we've had a number of questions via the webcast platform, principally surrounding the known [ph] Zara concepts. The first of which is, at Zara Home, we see strong growth in store numbers and also in terms of larger store sizes. Are you also expanding in the Southern Hemisphere? What is changing your assessment of this concept in order to enter into these sorts of initiatives?

---

Well, I think this question has been raised during the conference call, so I wouldn't say what -- I would repeat what I was saying before, that we are very pleased with the performance of Zara Home, and we are developing the brand in the different geographies, both through relevant store openings and through online. Zara Home is a brand which is very, very well accepted in all the different geographies in which we are introducing the brand and developing. And in the presentation, we were mentioning this relevant enlargement of the most important flagship today of Zara Home in the world and, at the same time, this online launch in Japan. In Japan, we also have stores with Zara Home, as you know, relevant stores in Tokyo and Osaka, in the different Japanese cities. So we'll continue developing the brand in the different markets.

---

Also, Pablo, perhaps you could expand on your thoughts on Oysho. We have another question on Oysho. Oysho seems to be back on track, and you have invested significantly in enlarging headquarters and the distribution center. Do you feel more confident about the prospects of this concept now?

---

Well, we have always feel -- felt confident with the prospects of Oysho. About the new headquarters, what Oysho is doing is to -- Oysho has moved to what used to be the Massimo Dutti headquarters in Barcelona, in Tordera. We built a new logistics platform and headquarters for Massimo Dutti, and then we have refurbished the former Massimo Dutti headquarters. And Oysho, because of its growth, has moved to what used to be the Massimo Dutti headquarters and also the Massimo Dutti logistic platform that now is the former one, that now is the Oysho logistic platform. We think we have very good product, very good store image. We are developing also new lines, very strong, the Gymwear Collection. Well, in the presentation, we have mentioned this new flagship in Paseo de Gracia in Barcelona, which is a very relevant one and which is showing the full range of products that we have now with Oysho. So our idea is to continue developing the brand in the coming years.

---

That's the final question from webcast. We have no more questions here.

---

Well, then thank you again to all of you. And in any case, of course, as always, we are ready to answer any questions you may have through our Capital Markets Department. Thank you very much for joining us during this conference call. Thank you.
